resources: "A The effect on price is indeterminate but quantity will fall. ENDSTOPB The effect on price is indeterminate but quantity will rise. ENDSTOPC The effect on quantity is indeterminate but price will rise. ENDSTOPD The effect on quantity is indeterminate but price will fall." "A 2.0 per cent. ENDSTOPB 2.5 per cent. ENDSTOPC 10 per cent. ENDSTOPD 38 per cent." "A an increase in incomes ENDSTOPB a rise in car prices ENDSTOPC an increase in petrol prices ENDSTOPD a rise in the price of rail travel" "A significant economies of scale ENDSTOPB heavy potential advertising costs ENDSTOPC large capital requirements ENDSTOPD constant returns to scale" "A increase as its output increases. ENDSTOPB decrease as its output increases. ENDSTOPC remain constant as its output increases. ENDSTOPD always be greater than its average variable costs of production." "A raise their price in the short run but the price will fall back to its original level in the long run. ENDSTOPB keep their price constant both in the short and in the long run. ENDSTOPC raise price in both the short run and the long run. ENDSTOPD keep price constant in the short run but raise their price in the long run." "A the market price to fall but quantity supplied to increase. ENDSTOPB the market price to rise but quantity supplied to fall. ENDSTOPC both market price and quantity supplied to rise. ENDSTOPD no change to the market price or quantity supplied." "A excess demand and shortages. ENDSTOPB excess supply and surpluses. ENDSTOPC excess demand and surpluses. ENDSTOPD excess supply and shortages." "A its marginal costs of production decrease. ENDSTOPB it is making excess profits. ENDSTOPC its fixed costs of production decrease. ENDSTOPD it is making a loss." "A When the monopolistically competitive industry achieves a long-run equilibrium, price is greater than marginal cost. ENDSTOPB Monopolistically competitive firms offer differentiated products and face a downward sloping demand curve. ENDSTOPC Under monopolistic competition, the price charged to the consumer is equal to the average revenue of the firm. ENDSTOPD Monopolistically competitive firms can earn supernormal profits in the long run." "A comparability ENDSTOPB indifference ENDSTOPC independence ENDSTOPD transitivity" "A fall at an increasing rate. ENDSTOPB fall at a decreasing rate. ENDSTOPC rise at an increasing rate. ENDSTOPD rise at a decreasing rate." "A marginal utility will rise. ENDSTOPB total utility will be unchanged. ENDSTOPC marginal utility will fall. ENDSTOPD money income is unchanged." "A be less than the average tax rate. ENDSTOPB be greater than the average tax rate. ENDSTOPC be equal to the average tax rate. ENDSTOPD initially be less than, but eventually greater than, the average tax rate." "A £180 million ENDSTOPB £200 million ENDSTOPC £220 million ENDSTOPD £240 million" "A Savings, taxes and investment are withdrawals. ENDSTOPB Exports, imports and government expenditure are withdrawals. ENDSTOPC Investment, government expenditure and exports are injections. ENDSTOPD Investment, exports and consumption are injections.." "A wages from self employment ENDSTOPB property rental income ENDSTOPC transfer payments ENDSTOPD net property income from abroad" "A The demand for money is interest elastic and private investment is interest inelastic. ENDSTOPB The demand for money is interest inelastic and private investment is interest elastic. ENDSTOPC The demand for money and private investment are both interest inelastic. ENDSTOPD The demand for money and private investment are both interest elastic." "A rise and reduce money demand. ENDSTOPB rise and raise money demand. ENDSTOPC fall and reduce money demand. ENDSTOPD fall and raise money demand." "A £500 million ENDSTOPB £700 million ENDSTOPC £1,000 million ENDSTOPD £1,300 million" "A rise in long term interest rates. ENDSTOPB increase in the money supply. ENDSTOPC a fall in bond prices. ENDSTOPD none of the above." "A increase the cash reserves of commercial banks and increase the monetary base. ENDSTOPB increase the cash reserves of commercial banks and reduce the monetary base. ENDSTOPC reduce the cash reserves of commercial banks and increase the monetary base. ENDSTOPD reduce the cash reserves of commercial banks and reduce the monetary base." "A The IS curve shifts left and the LM curve remains in the same place. ENDSTOPB The IS curve shifts right and the LM curve remains in the same place. ENDSTOPC The LM curve shifts left and the IS curve remains in the same place. ENDSTOPD The LM curve shifts right and the IS curve remains in the same place." "A investment is increased when interest rates fall. ENDSTOPB an increase in investment will lead to a proportionate increase in output. ENDSTOPC the rate of change of investment is directly proportional to the rate of change of output. ENDSTOPD small fluctuations in national income can lead to large fluctuations in investment demand." "A Country A has a comparative advantage and an absolute advantage in producing Good Y. ENDSTOPB Country B has a comparative advantage in producing Good X and an absolute advantage in producing Good Y. ENDSTOPC Country A has a comparative advantage in producing Good Y and an absolute advantage in producing Good X. ENDSTOPD Country B has a comparative advantage in producing Good Y and an absolute advantage in producing Good X." "A An appreciation of a country’s exchange rate will increase its import volumes and decrease its export volumes. ENDSTOPB An appreciation of a country’s exchange rate will increase its import expenditure and decrease its export revenues. ENDSTOPC A depreciation of a country’s exchange rate will decrease its import volumes and decrease its export volumes. ENDSTOPD A depreciation of a country’s exchange rate will decrease its import expenditure and increase its export revenues."
